Text_4: Kini anaknya yang kian sudah bertumbuh dewasa seakan tidak pernah lupa dengan perkataan sang ibu ‚ÄúJadilah orang yang berhasil di dunia ini jangan sombong dan angkuh sesungguhnya semua itu hanyalah titipan dari Yang Maha Kuasa dan doa ibu selalu menyertai di mana kau berada.‚Äù Ya seburuk apapun kita ibu selalu senantiasa mencintai sepenuh hati dan mendoakan anaknya untuk menjadi orang yang berhasil di kemudian hari.
Name_5: Lirik Lagu 'Cinta Diujung Nafas' yang Dipopulerkan Oleh Wali Band
Text_5:
Sonora.ID - Cinta Diujung Nafas adalah salah satu single yang pernah dibawakan oleh Wali Band. Single ini diciptakan oleh sang gitaris Wali yang lebih dikenal dengan Apoy.

Single ini termasuk kedalam salah satu album wali yang bertajuk 20 20.

Cinta Diujung Nafas sendiri pertama kali diperdengarkan ke muka publik pada tahun 2020 silam. Lagu ini juga diunggah pada kanal youtube melalui channel Wali-Topik.

Name: Cisco
Name_1: Minnesota landowners hold keys to protect forests cold water lakes
Text_1:
From a wooded shore Wabedo Lake stretches out in classic Minnesota North Woods form: a few docks stands of rippling wild rice a small fishing boat quietly gliding by.

The Siemering family wanted to guarantee future generations could have the kind of lake experience they have cherished. So instead of selling their 116 acres of lakeshore forest for development they turned to the Northern Waters Land Trust. The family sold it to the conservation nonprofit which in turn conveyed it to Cass County ensuring the forest will never be altered or built on and will be open to the public to use.

The forest is thick with undisturbed birch aspen basswood balsam and spruce.

"Probably the greatest thing now is this place that we have cherished and brought so many memories ‚Ä¶ this one slice is now being protected" said Cheryl Siemering 64 of Plymouth. "It just continues to live on then."

The sale is one piece in the puzzle of efforts to save the state's special cold-water lakes by protecting the forest around them. The lakes and their critical fish habitat are at serious risk under relentless pressure from the spread of row-crop farming farther north commercial development landowners clearing lakefront property nutrient runoff from farm and lawn chemicals and climate change's rising temperatures.

Most Minnesotans probably don't realize how unique their cold-water lakes are said Kathy DonCarlos land conservation lead for the Northern Waters Land Trust. They only exist in the northern tier states she said. Illinois for example doesn't have them.

The Wabedo Lake purchase is particularly exciting the trust said because it's a large parcel. Plus while people are still selling land for conservation land donations have slowed with the tax code changes under the Trump administration that reduced deductibility for all charitable contributions.

Trust conservation specialist Annie Knight called such land sales a "concrete and permanent" way private landowners can take charge of preserving nature for future generations.

"Restoration costs way more money than simply protecting it in the first place" Knight said.

The focus of the Walker-based Northern Waters Land Trust is preserving forestland around strategic lakes in Cass Crow Wing Hubbard and Aitkin counties. Since the 1990s it has bought or received 1481 acres. Working with the Minnesota Land Trust it has arranged conservation easements on an additional 3197 acres. With such easements landowners agree not to further develop the land.

Wabedo Lake in Cass County is one of 620 official tullibee lakes in Minnesota that provide habitat for the fish also known as cisco whose populations have been crashing in the Midwest. The trust is focusing on protecting land on tullibee lakes and lakes with broader outstanding biological significance.

Tullibee are small silvery fish that thrive in well-oxygenated cold water. A type of herring they're a critical forage fish for prized game fish such as walleye and muskie so densely nutritious that they're called nature's Snickers for fish.

Fish-to-forest tipping point

The DNR relies on a calculated fish-to-forest tipping point ‚Äî if at least 75% of a lake's watershed is protected with forest cover the lakes there can sustain themselves ‚Äî and their cold-water fish. Forests are a perfect water conditioner a sponge that slows rain soaks it up prevents erosion filters water and cools it.

The Siemerings did not know all this at first of course. Cheryl Siemering and her brother John 73 who lives outside Pittsburgh just knew it was time to let go of the treasured lake home.

The Wabedo Lake property had been in the extended family since the 1940s. Their mother's cousin ran Blakemen's Resort there. Then their parents Robert and Alice bought it in the 1970s and changed the name to the Loon's Nest Resort which they ran for 20 years. They retired there taking down all but one of the five small cabins. Robert died while fishing on the lake in 2003. Alice died in February at 98.

"It was everything to her" Cheryl Siemering said of the lake. "She loved it so."

But the family had scattered and the property was becoming too much to manage.

John Siemering said Pat Moran of Moran Realty in nearby Longville first told them about the Northern Waters Land Trust's preservation effort in 2017 after seeing the property.

"There were no docks. It was exactly the way it was made by God or whoever" Moran said. "It was a big beautiful chunk on the lake."

Moran said his father worked for years as a DNR forestry supervisor and coached him about seeing the highest and best use for land.

"That rules" Moran said. "I've seen these pieces that I just think: 'You know I don't need to develop that.' "

They called Cass County Land Commissioner Kirk Titus who also drove out for a look. He said he saw more than 800 feet of undisturbed shoreline on land abutting 1800 acres of public forest land the county already maintains.

Titus said it fit perfectly with the county's goal of conserving land to protect wildlife habitat and public access for recreation: hunting fishing hiking berry picking and wildlife viewing. The conservation deal also had strong support from the Wabedo-Little Boy-Cooper-Rice Lakes Association which put money toward the purchase as did the Hugh C. Becker Foundation.

"I think I'm going to call it Siemering Woods" Titus said.

Cheryl Siemering said that as they learned more about how conserving forest around a lake supports the lake's overall health "we were [in] hook line and sinker."

'Thrilled that we did it'

The Northern Waters Land Trust had the 116-acre parcel appraised and bought it for an undisclosed sum with grant money from the sales-tax-based Outdoor Heritage Fund. The fund is one created by the state's Clean Water Land and Legacy Amendment.

The Siemerings carved out a small parcel with their mother's house on it for a separate sale. A couple planning to retire there just bought that piece Cheryl said.

It is their first summer not being at the lake John said. But they know the conservation sale was the right move ‚Äî and they said they are grateful their mother lived to see it completed.

About 10 days before she passed John said she said out of the blue: " 'You know John whatever happens I'm so happy we did what we did with the property.' "

"She said the same thing to my sister" he said. "She was thrilled that we did it."

A family that lived on Wabedo Lake in Cass County for decades decided to sell their more than 100 acres of undeveloped woods and shoreline to the Northern Waters Land Trust so it remains undeveloped.

"More people should know about this."

Jennifer Bjorhus ‚Ä¢ 612-673-4683

Correction: Previous versions of this story misstated Wabedo Lake's status and the number of tullibee refuge lakes in Minnesota.
Name_2: Giant fork police lawsuit and island Airbnb: top New Bedford stories
Text_2:
Standard-Times

NEW BEDFORD ‚Äî Despite a sleepy holiday week the New Bedford area enjoyed a fireworks display of a different kind thanks to some big news stories.

In case you missed them here are the top five most-read stories this week on southcoasttoday.com.

New Bedford's future looks bright

Will Silverstein who grew up working in restaurants owned by his father Steve Silverstein is no stranger to the local hospitality scene. Readers are surely familiar with his father's restaurants ‚Äî from Not Your Average Joe's to the Black Whale to the new Cisco Brewers Entertainment Complex at the old Davy's Locker site.

More:Exclusive first look: Touring New Bedford‚Äôs Cisco Brewers entertainment complex

After finishing his degree at Cornell University and stints at New Your City restaurants Will is back in New Bedford taking the wheel at Cultivator Shoals helping out with Original Kitchen and Bar in Dartmouth and the Whale's Tail clam bar.

He's got plenty of ideas for New Bedford's future too.

‚ÄúI think there's a whole next generation who are these intellectuals pushing New Bedford forward. I‚Äôm happy to be part of it" he said. ‚ÄúThe potential is there.‚Äù

Read the story here:This 5th-generation restaurateur has big plans for New Bedford's hip and happening future

New Bedford Police subject of discrimination lawsuit

A female former New Bedford police officer filed a lawsuit last month alleging three officers including a former police chief created a hostile workplace and engaged in gender discrimination and retaliation.

Macaila Saunders now a school resource officer for the Swansea Police Department alleges that in 2018 and 2019 Lt. Scott Carola now the department's public information officer and chief's administrative assistant created a hostile work environment based on gender and exhibited "demeaning actions."

Saunders also alleges defendants Joseph Cordeiro who served as police chief from 2016 to April 2021 and Adelino Sousa who became deputy chief Wednesday engaged in gender discrimination and retaliation and aided in Carola's alleged treatment of Saunders.

Read the story here:Ex-New Bedford police officer sues officers and city alleging gender discrimination

Crow Island's new owner has big plans

Crow Island once described in the late 1800s as place where squatters built their lean-tos and shanties has a new owner who is working to convert the island into an Airbnb.

Al Santos bought the island about two years ago and while he isn‚Äôt making any drastic changes to the main house he has spruced up the landscaping and the nautical artistic pieces and sculptures that dot the grounds.

The island had been owned since 1979 by Carl Pimentel the New Bedford entrepreneur and restaurateur who owned the Smuggler‚Äôs Den nightclub in New Bedford‚Äôs South End. Pimentel turned the property into his own private paradise and kept it that way until his death in August 2018.

Read the story here:From Airbnb to weddings: How the new owner plans to transform Fairhaven's Crow Island

Ever notice that fork in the road?

There‚Äôs a larger-than-life carving of an actual fork placed at the River and Old Harbor Roads split .in Westport and it's the brainchild of Tom Schmitt who constructed the fork back in 2010 after the idea came to him when he was at a local sawmill to get wood for a different project.

The project kept him busy as he pieced the fork together using a real fork for scale.

The fork gets dressed up for the holidays. It dons a heart for Valentine‚Äôs Day a Santa had on Christmas and a hot dog on the Fourth of July.

Read the story here:Curious SouthCoast: Westport's fork in the road carving is a place setting curiosity

Some favorite brunch spots on the SouthCoast

With the return of summer festivities and the easing of COVID-related dining restrictions now is a great time to meet up with friends or take the family for a late-morning meal out. After a year of missed brunch dates you have a lot of catching up to do and a lot of fun local food options to explore.

We offered some cozy places to check out that offer their unique twists on the beloved breakfast/lunch combo.

Read the story here:Let's brunch: A taste of some must-try brunch spots in the SouthCoast

Name_4: New report: Coors Field gets Wi-Fi 6 upgrade ahead of All-Star Game
Text_4:
by

Stadium Tech Report is pleased to announce our Summer 2021 issue which includes an in-depth profile of the new Wi-Fi 6 network upgrade at the Colorado Rockies‚Äô Coors Field which will host the Major League Baseball All-Star Game this July. Planned ahead of the pandemic the Coors Field network upgrade includes new equipment from Cisco and some innovative design and deployment tactics from integrator AmpThink the Colorado Rockies and MLB. With a full house expected for the July 12-13 events Coors Field is ready to go from a Wi-Fi connectivity standpoint including coverage at the new McGregor Square area adjacent to the ballpark.

We also have a profile of a new esports facility deployment at the University of Arizona done by a new firm called 1337 Facilities which is led by stadium technology veteran Bob Jordan. One more story looks into the possibilities presented by smart poles which can bring connectivity and other technology features to parking lots. Take a read and tell us what you think!

If you are reading on a desktop or tablet you can view all the stories in our web magazine format.

We‚Äôd like to take a quick moment to thank our sponsors which for this issue include Corning Boingo MatSing Cox Business/Hospitality Network American Tower CommScope AmpThink and Belden. Their generous sponsorship makes it possible for us to offer this content free of charge to our readers. We‚Äôd also like to welcome readers from the Inside Towers community who may have found their way here via our ongoing partnership with the excellent publication Inside Towers.
Name_5: Mohammed bin Rashid launches the National Program for Coders the largest ever UAE initiative to foster the ...
Text_5:
- His Highness: The National Program for Coders is a major step in the development of the UAE‚Äôs digital economy



‚Ä¢ Initiative launched in collaboration with Google Microsoft Amazon Cisco IBM HPE LinkedIn Nvidia and Facebook

‚Ä¢ The Program seeks to train and attract 100000 coders and establish 1000 digital companies in 5 years

‚Ä¢ Investment in startups to be increased from AED1.5 billion to AED4 billion

‚Ä¢ Initiative seeks to make the UAE the world‚Äôs foremost destination for coders and future innovators

‚Ä¢ Golden Visas to be granted to 100000 of the world‚Äôs best coders



Government of Dubai Media Office ‚Äì 10 July 2021: His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai today said that the growth of the digital economy is a major priority for the government as part of which the UAE seeks to accelerate the development of the country‚Äôs talent and expertise in the sector. Nurturing and empowering advanced skills represents a major pillar of the nation‚Äôs strategy for building a thriving digital future driven by advances in science knowledge innovation and technology. The UAE‚Äôs success in digital and technological transformation is a key enabler of its strategic plans His Highness said.

HH Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid today launched a major new initiative to foster the growth of the digital economy titled the ‚ÄòNational Program for Coders‚Äô. The landmark Program will introduce a series of national initiatives to develop talent expertise and innovation in the field of coding. The initiative seeks to accelerate the adoption of digital applications and tools in various economic and future-oriented sectors by promoting close links and interaction between coders and public and private organisations and academic entities.

Announcing the new initiative on Twitter His Highness said: ‚ÄúToday we launched the National Program for Coders in collaboration with Google Microsoft Amazon Cisco IBM Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) LinkedIn Nvidia and Facebook with the aim of training and attracting 100000 coders establishing 1000 digital companies within five years and increasing investment in startups from AED1.5 billion to AED4 billion‚Äù.

In another tweet His Highness said the Program represents a major new step in developing the UAE‚Äôs digital economy. ‚ÄúThe world is rapidly changing and the fast-growing digital economy will create new types of jobs. To thrive in the ever-evolving world we must be ready to quickly cope with the emerging trends.‚Äù

His Highness further said: ‚ÄúOur youth need to know that the future has new tools speaks a different language and adopts online work methodologies. We want them to be at the heart of this future. The National Program for Coders aims to engage local digital communities in the digital transformation of the UAE. It further highlights the UAE‚Äôs leading role in designing the future embracing talent entrepreneurs academics startups global companies and future investments globally".

"We seek to attract the best international coders and provide them with the infrastructure needed to develop innovative ideas that serve the world. We aim to establish 1000 startups in the field of digital economy in the UAE within five years. We will support national coders in developing themselves into the best in the world. We will employ promising talent in the development of 10 platforms for supporting social and humanitarian projects in the UAE.‚Äù

His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid issued directives to all government entities in the UAE to support the development of national and international coding talent; work with legislative bodies business incubators investment companies universities and research centres to support coding-based initiatives and projects that foster national talent in the field; and further develop the legislative framework to enable the UAE to keep pace with rapid global changes and the latest technological advances.

Supporting National Efforts

Under the supervision of the UAE Artificial Intelligence Office the ‚ÄòNational Program for Coders‚Äô aims to support national initiatives and future strategies in the UAE designed to develop the capabilities of national talent attract global digital skills and build the infrastructure necessary to establish broader innovation-based companies.

The Program further enables coding entrepreneurs businesses and startups to support digital transformation in various key sectors. It also seeks to provide opportunities for fostering cooperation between government and private sector entities in the UAE and abroad to implement promising ideas and turn them into comprehensive projects.

His Excellency Omar Sultan Al Olama Minister of State for Artificial Intelligence Digital Economy and Remote Work Applications said that the launch of the National Program for Coders is a major milestone in the UAE‚Äôs development into a global digital powerhouse. The Program reflects the country‚Äôs determination to be among the vanguard of nations shaping the world‚Äôs future he said.

"The UAE has always been a driver of excellence in advanced sectors. The launch of the National Program for Coders is another vital step in ensuring our future growth is driven by knowledge and innovation. The country‚Äôs leadership has always believed in the crucial role played by advanced technology in economic and social progress and has been committed to harnessing new value for the country the region and the world from the latest advances through strategic initiatives. The UAE will always serve as a hub for the development of creative and innovative solutions for the world‚Äôs challenges. We will work closely with our partners and stakeholders to achieve the Program‚Äôs goals and create the most supportive environment for coders from around the world to develop their skills and talent‚Äù His Excellency said.

Five Key Strategic Pillars

The National Program for Coders focuses on five key pillars which include: supporting coders entrepreneurs startups large companies and the academic sector; developing a comprehensive platform for promoting engagement and linkages between coders and local companies and universities; launching global skill development initiatives featuring international trainers aimed at enhancing the efficiency of local talent; attracting the best International coding professionals to the UAE and recommending policies to foster the development of the coding sector in cooperation with various government entities.

Supporting Strategic Objectives

Several initiatives will be launched to support the strategy‚Äôs goals including a comprehensive platform to link coders with the private and academic sectors supporting businesses in finding specialised talent to develop innovative projects providing the Golden Visa to some of the world‚Äôs leading coders developing the skills and expertise of Emirati coders so that they can be among the world‚Äôs best supporting national digital economy start-ups and empowering social and humanitarian coding-based projects.

As part of the support provided by the Program it will help various government entities develop innovative coding-based solutions in cooperation with leading coders independent businesses local startups and global coding companies. It will also oversee the skill development of young Emirati coders in addition to studying and identifying local and global market needs and enhancing continuous cooperation with the academic sector.

100000 Golden Visas

The National Program for Coding launched by His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum will grant Golden Visas to 100000 of the world‚Äôs best coders. It will also provide a range of financing options to entrepreneurs and coders support the implementation of their innovative projects and ideas and establish digital companies to promote the competitiveness of the national economy worldwide.

Developing Innovative Solutions to 100 Challenges

In its next phase the Program will invite coders from around the world to find innovative solutions to 100 government economic technological health and services challenges and help accelerate the adoption of modern technologies. The Program will also organise 10 hackathons bringing together top-notch coders to support national efforts in developing an integrated system in the UAE based on the latest technologies.

#UAE_Codes

A comprehensive global campaign will be launched to highlight the UAE‚Äôs efforts in attracting the world‚Äôs best coding professionals. It will also provide services and encourage coders to find jobs and establish startups in the UAE.

National and Global Partnerships

To realise the vision of His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum achieve the strategic goals of the major new initiative and implement all related initiatives and projects the National Program for Coders will develop partnerships with multiple public private and academic entities and technology companies in the UAE and abroad including Google Microsoft IBM LinkedIn Facebook Huawei Amazon Web Services (AWS) Nvidia Cisco Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) Majid Al Futtaim Dubai World Trade Centre Emirates NBD Group 42 (G42) Khalifa University Higher Colleges of Technology University of Sharjah Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence (MBZUAI) American University in Dubai (AUD) Le Wagon and Yalla.

Name_2: Back to banking former Jonesboro Mayor Harold Perrin finds a new role for growing the community
Text_2:
Former Jonesboro Mayor Harold Perrin returned to his banking roots a little over six months ago after 12 years as the city‚Äôs CEO. He cited a major health issue as one reason for bowing out of the job he‚Äôd held for more than a decade during a period of unprecedented regional growth.

Now serving as senior vice president business development for First Security Bank in Jonesboro Perrin still has an eye on how the city develops particularly from his private sector position.

An Arkansas State University alumni Perrin has three additional banking-related degrees from Southern Methodist University Northwestern University and Louisiana State University. He previously worked for Citizens Bank Jonesboro First National Bank Batesville and served as president at both First State Bank Newport and Mercantile Bank Jonesboro. He also has consulted a broad range of firms on financial matters through a private management company.

Perrin visited with Talk Business & Politics Editor-in-Chief Roby Brock to discuss his transition out of the public limelight his developing role at the bank and what he sees happening in the region‚Äôs marketplace.

TB&P: For starters how is your health?

Harold Perrin: I just went to the doctor today and was scoped and got a negative bill from the local urologist here in town who coordinates with MD Anderson [Cancer Center]. So I‚Äôm very blessed very pleased that so far everything is going good.

TB&P: You‚Äôve been out of office for about six months now. What it‚Äôs like to not be the mayor of Jonesboro? How‚Äôs the transition back to the private sector going?

Perrin: I was only retired for about two weeks and I‚Äôd get some calls from various companies. Then good friends of mine Reynie Rutledge and Brad Edwards called me and we sat down and had two or three meetings. It‚Äôs just like coming back home really. When I had my own company First Security Bank was my client for 14 years. So I know a lot of people that are still here and I like the way Reynie operates his financial institutions.

I‚Äôm just really happy content and excited. My wife says that when I come home at night you don‚Äôt have to go to all those meetings like you used to. That‚Äôs the one thing I miss. I will tell you that I do miss being mayor a little bit. I still have the opportunity to visit with some of the department heads from time to time when I run into them at a restaurant or outside the bank.

But the key to both jobs require two things: relationships and partnerships. That‚Äôs really what we‚Äôre doing here at the bank. It is the same thing I did as mayor.

TB&P: What are you seeing in the marketplace right now as a loan officer as a person that‚Äôs involved in economic development. What‚Äôs hot right now?

Perrin: I would say two things are just absolutely going strong. Number one is housing. It seems like every council meeting they approve a complete subdivision. Right now you‚Äôve got several new subdivisions under construction.

The other thing very close to that is commercial as well as retail. When I say retail a lot of that is tied back to food. We‚Äôre getting a Chipotle‚Äôs Freddy‚Äôs has just opened up. We‚Äôre getting a lot of that here in town as well. So I would say housing restaurants and retail is your big thing.

But let me say this we just went through last year dedicating some of the largest projects for the hospitals. The tower at St. Bernards and the ICU rooms as well as NEA Baptist which is now under construction. They are building doctors‚Äô clinics away from the hospital because they need the space within the hospital.

TB&P: What do you think is missing? What are the ingredients that Jonesboro and Northeast Arkansas need more of?

Perrin: One I think the chamber [Jonesboro Chamber of Commerce] is now looking for additional land. We are pretty close to only a few hundred acres around 600. We‚Äôre going to need more than that.

We‚Äôve also got a master railroad expansion master plan. There‚Äôs work to get the funding for that. The other thing is that we‚Äôre working with the airport to look at the terminal. We‚Äôve got a good terminal now but I think the expansion of that we‚Äôre going to have to enlarge that.

In the area of employment I would like to see us concentrate on good high-tech jobs and industry in that area. That‚Äôs one of the goals of Jonesboro Unlimited when they raised the funds to do that. One of them was to look at high-tech companies. They go to trade shows et cetera and work in that area. They‚Äôre doing a good job. We hit our goals the first year which I think is great.

We‚Äôve been blessed as a city. I always said that when I cut a ribbon that it‚Äôs a great day in Jonesboro but it‚Äôs also a blessed day. I mean that sincerely and the fact that we always want to be pro-business. We‚Äôve got a lot of good things going. It just takes time to get it to completion. You‚Äôve just got to have a little patience and sometimes my patience is short.

We all work as a team and I think that‚Äôs the big key is that none of us is looking for credit. We‚Äôre looking to get whatever we need for Jonesboro for our people and it doesn‚Äôt make any difference whether you‚Äôre with the chamber the university the city or a financial institution. We‚Äôre going to get together work together and get it completed.
Name_3: Norman Kay Connell Obituary - The Indianapolis Star
Text_3:
Norman Kay Connell

Mooresville ‚Äì Norman Kay Connell (81) passed away on July 10 2021 after an extended struggle with Pancreatic Cancer. Norman was born on October 31 1939 the youngest son of Leland R. and Britta M. (Laughlin) Connell. Early in life he and his brother Max lived with their Aunt Doris and Uncle Iven Connell in Dana IN for nine years. He then returned to Mooresville to live with Leland and his stepmom Orda Jane (Burris) Connell.

Norman graduated from Mooresville High School in 1957 and enlisted in the U.S. Air Force. Upon being discharged in 1961 he began his career at Citizens Bank in Mooresville. Norman progressed through a series of positions at the bank before serving as President and CEO from 1975 until his retirement in 2001. He then served on the Board of Directors until 2009. During his banking career Norman attended classes at Indiana University Indiana Central College and graduated from the School of Banking Administration at the University of Wisconsin in 1976. Then in 1977 Norman graduated from the Commercial Lending School of the American Banking Association at the University of Oklahoma. In addition to his career in banking he served on the board of many civic and service organizations including the Mooresville Lions Club Mooresville Chamber of Commerce Mooresville Library Board Mooresville Revitalization Group Mooresville Redevelopment Commission Mooresville Nature Club Kendrick Memorial Hospital Kendrick Foundation and Indiana Bankers Association. He received a Sagamore of the Wabash award from Governor Robert Orr in 1987 and again from Governor Frank O'Bannon in 2001. He was named 'Mooresvillian of the Year' by the Mooresville Chamber of Commerce in 1993 and received the Distinguished Alumnus Award from the Mooresville High School Alumni Association in 1997. After retirement he served in a variety of positions at the Mooresville Friends Church Western Yearly Meeting of Friends and Friends United Meeting.

He was preceded in death by his parents and a daughter Malinda Lee Haltom.

Survivors include his wife of 58 years Ruth (Key) Connell and children: Rebecca Connell (Tim Sheridan) William "Todd" Connell (Barbara) and John Connell (Kelly) nine grandchildren four great-grandchildren and brother Max Connell.

Norman's Life Celebration¬Æ visitation and funeral service will be held at Carlisle - Branson Funeral Service & Crematory 39 E. High St. Mooresville. Visitation will be Wednesday July 14 2021 4 to 8 p.m. with services beginning at 10:30 a.m. Thursday July 15 2021. Burial will be in White Lick Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions can be made to the Mooresville Friends Church 50 N. Monroe Street Mooresville IN 46158. Visit www.CarlisleBranson.com to share a favorite memory or to sign the online guest registry.
Name_4: Development in neglected east Oklahoma City gets national attention
Text_4:
In the middle of the east side of Oklahoma City along the main street of the local African American community a success story is rising against all odds and is attracting national attention as a possible model for overcoming decades of discrimination and systemic racism.

It took a few years to get built but EastPoint at NE 23 and Rhode Island is complete and home to a dream list of tenants for any neglected neighborhood.

The project started with redevelopment of a boarded-up former truck stop and a decision by Centennial Health formerly known as Oklahoma City Clinic to anchor EastPoint with its headquarters and healthcare center. Next door area residents are enjoying a non-profit grocery operated by Homeland and featuring fresh produce from a nearby farm operated by Restore OKC.

'This is for the community':Grocery opens in NE OKC 'food desert'

The second phase of development tackled a worn-down retail strip across the street from the clinic and grocery. The transformed center is now home to a fitness center bar bookstore optometrist and offices with a pizzeria and coffee shop to open soon.

And in a unique twist aimed at preventing outside gentrification the Black-owned businesses opening in the retail strip are each offered an opportunity to include an equity stake in the building as part of their leases.

A national panel of judges with the Urban Land Institute toured the development in June. A documentary about EastPoint created by Stout Media and the project‚Äôs architects at Gardner Studio won the grand prize from the American Institute of Architects‚Äô annual national film challenge.

Seth Levine and Elizabeth MacBride also made the trek to NE 23 as they researched their book ‚ÄúThe New Builders: Face to Face with the TRUE Future of Business.‚Äù The authors say EastPoint was one of their first focuses as they sought to chronicle the diversity of minority entrepreneurs starting businesses at a rate that outpaces any other entrepreneurial group in the country.

‚ÄúEastPoint is quite innovative‚Äù Levine said. ‚ÄúIt solves problems of outside developers coming into neighborhoods who are well-intentioned but end up building projects that force residents out of their neighborhoods.‚Äù

MacBride said they were intrigued at the array of challenges overcome by the EastPoint team starting with the legacy of discriminatory investment and lending for both developers and business owners like Emmanuel Sosanya who now operates a fitness gym there.

‚ÄúThere is a ton of big money in the world to help communities like on the east side but not a lot of people who can figure out how to put that together‚Äù MacBride said. ‚ÄúHow do you fund a fitness gym in EastPoint? What he needs is a form of finance that helps him build wealth in his company. But what he needs is $5000 to $12000. There are banks that want to loan millions but not at the amount he needs.‚Äù

Neighborhoods:OKC scrapyard operator to build 30-foot wall in response to blast complaints by neighbors

Faded community

Sandino Thompson grew up in northeast Oklahoma City. His parents Wayne and Melba Thompson were civic leaders on the east side with a long list of efforts to improve healthcare and improve prospects for Black youth. His grandmother Daisy Mitchell helped establish the Mary Mahoney Center.

‚ÄúMy grandmother‚Äôs house is around the corner‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúI grew up spending time here during the summers so I‚Äôm very familiar with 23rd Street.‚Äù

The area faded over time he said.

‚ÄúWhen we were growing up I‚Äôd be here in the summer and I‚Äôd walk on 23rd Street to go to the stores walk to the grocery and different businesses‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúBy the time I was in high school this wasn‚Äôt a place where you would walk anywhere on 23rd. It wasn‚Äôt that place anymore.‚Äù

But hope endured. Thompson grew up in a family of activists his parents always pushing for change and improvement. He was familiar with the starts and stops to rekindle the community and bring back economic development.

A lot of the discussions took place at the Ralph Ellison Library at NE 23 and Martin Luther King Avenue.

‚ÄúWhenever there were events like that how we could get things going and see revitalization in this part of town they would be held at the library‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of people I knew who owned property that fell into disrepair. They didn‚Äôt know what to do with it and often they didn‚Äôt have the means to follow through with the ideas they had.‚Äù

Interstate 235 is the dividing line between east and west Oklahoma City. And while NE 23 was stagnating a different story was taking place along NW 23 where similarly neglected commercial buildings were coming back to life with restaurants bars and entertainment venues.

The Pivot Project a group started by David Wanzer Jonathan Dodson and Ben Sellers (who has since left the partnership) was building a track record of successfully redeveloping older properties including the iconic Tower Theatre and an adjoining strip of abandoned storefronts.

Thompson got to know Dodson a former banker as the pair served on the Bricktown Design Review Committee. The pair started talking about dreams of bringing similar development to NE 23. The Oklahoma City Clinic was looking to leave its long-time home at the Oklahoma Health Center and rebrand itself as Centennial Health Clinic.

Thompson joining with the Pivot Project did a deal with Centennial Health to move its headquarters and operate its clinic in the former Cleary‚Äôs Service Station at 1720 NE 23.

‚ÄúThe assumption was if we have the capital a development group that has an inclusive approach to development and we have local community partners and leaders involved this should be pretty easy‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúWe have an anchor tenant; we know what this looks like and we know what we‚Äôre facing.‚Äù

OKC Central:Owner of Classen Curve Triangle Nichols Hills Plaza files for bankruptcy

Overcoming history

The development team hoped they had all the ingredients to attract financing. They had the support of the mayor and council and were in communication with community leaders. Two dozen banks declined to finance EastPoint.

‚ÄúWe would tell them the location and they would say ‚ÄòOh well we really haven‚Äôt loaned money on that side of town‚Äô ‚ÄòWe haven‚Äôt really done things on that side of town‚Äô ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt have comps‚Äô ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre not sure about appraisals.'‚Äù

After decades of redlining and flight of capital how could the east side provide comps which help banks track property values and lending patterns? These bankers weren‚Äôt necessarily racist Thompson said but he believes it all comes back to the systemic racism that plagues Black communities throughout the country.

‚ÄúDespite having the guys who brought the Tower Theatre back the guys celebrated around town for pulling off some tricky developments challenging developments that they made work and have success to have them at the table and the full-on support of our council person and community leaders we couldn‚Äôt get financing‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúWe couldn‚Äôt get a bank to spend a lot of time with us.‚Äù

White flight hit the east side in the 1950s and 1960s as the African American community battled for civil rights and an end to Jim Crow. The GI Bill and federal housing programs started after World War II were not equitably applied Thompson said.

‚ÄúSometimes the laws were explicitly meant to discourage Black homeownership and particularly in primarily white communities‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúAs some of that began to change you had white flight to the suburbs and this became a community and corridor for the African American community.‚Äù

The city quit investing in the east side; streets and sidewalks crumbled and neighborhoods were not protected from encroaching industrial properties. Black families invested in the community began to see diminishing returns Thompson said.

The community lost voices to advocate for its well-being.

‚ÄúA lot of Black families that could moved for better schools better opportunities and better ways to maintain their value primarily with home ownership‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúWe saw wealth flight.‚Äù

Ultimately it was a community banker Jill Castilla CEO of Citizens Bank of Edmond who first agreed to tackle the financing challenge.

More:Innovative approach earns awards for Edmond banker

Dodson arranged with Cathy O‚ÄôConnor president of The Alliance for Economic Development of Oklahoma City to help him obtain tax increment financing from the city to help fill the financing gap and also to structure leases to allow retail tenants in the second phase to have an ownership stake in the property.

‚ÄúThese are two properties built in the 1920s and 1930‚Äù Dodson said. ‚ÄúThe real estate itself is not something that is incredible. What we wanted to do was to treat it well and spend the right amount of money. Where it really came down to was what would the equity and the debt look like and how do you make those numbers work on this side of town?‚Äù

The city invested 26% of the overall project costs of both phases through tax increment financing. To close the deal the team sought help from Steve Mason an investor developer and philanthropist dedicated to doing community-oriented projects.

‚ÄúIt took someone like Steve Mason to say ‚ÄòI‚Äôll join you guys and be part of the project so banks will finance it‚Äô‚Äù Dodson said. ‚ÄúIt really highlights what someone like Steve Mason can do in changing the narrative of banks lending over here.‚Äù

Travel and tourism:Route 66 'refuge' for Black travelers now listed among 'most endangered' historic places

The triumph of Black-owned businesses

Only one space remains available at EastPoint. Intentional Fitness opened by Emmanuel Sosanya is proving a gym can draw customers a largely African American clientele back to NE 23. Chaya Fletcher who previously operated a popular music venue and restaurant in Deep Deuce teamed up with Quinton Hughes and is enjoying good crowds at Kindred Spirits a bar at EastPoint with a lit-up covered courtyard.

The Market at EastPoint recently opened at Centennial Health. The market is owned by the non-profit RestoreOKC which employs neighborhood teens at a nearby urban farm. The non-profit market sells produce from the farm while Homeland stocks the store with the products found at its other stores but with some at discounted pricing provided by suppliers.

More::OKC regulates dollar stores in 73111 ZIP code looks to create better health outcomes

Synexus a medical research firm was the final addition to the former truck stop.

The retail center design by Gardner Studio turned one storefront into an open air bay so that offices could line a corridor linking the street side of the center to the rear parking lot.

In addition to Intentional Fitness and Kindred Spirits the retail center is home to Looksee Eyecare and offices for community agency Public Strategies; Alori Chanel an art gallery and event space; Belle Books Boutique; and Moanch Properties an African-American owned homebuilding company founded by two sisters Monique Short and Erica Emery.

All of businesses are owned by African-Americans as are the next two tenants Spiked a Coffee Concept being opened soon by Brittani Hunter and Eastside Pizza House being opened later this summer by rapper and civic activist Jabee Williams.

Hunter is a newcomer to the east side but her family‚Äôs legacy is in Tulsa‚Äôs Greenwood where her grandfather operated a dry-cleaning business for decades. Hunter was working with the Thunder and had started embarking on a career in sports management when the pandemic hit.

Sidelined at home she found an old journal in which she had detailed the idea for a coffee shop that would serve its drinks ‚Äúspiked.‚Äù Driving along NE 23 she saw EastPoint and turned her dream into reality.

‚ÄúWe have almost everything you can get at a coffee shop down the street but we spike it‚Äù Hunter says with a laugh. ‚ÄúSo if you like rum Kahlua whiskey or vodka we‚Äôll have it. And we have a kids‚Äô table too; they‚Äôre welcome to come get some whipped cream and a piece of cake.‚Äù

Her grandmother is making the pastries cupcakes cookies cheesecakes and pound cakes with her own recipes. The menu also will include charcuterie boards spinach artichoke dip and humus.

She credits the EastPoint team with helping her get the business financed and started.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know anything about it anything about Pivot anything about the people here‚Äù Hunter said. ‚ÄúBut I was attracted to how much of a family it is. Sandino and Quinton brought me under their wing agreed we need a coffee shop and told me ‚ÄòDo what you need to do.‚Äô‚Äù

Early on her real estate agent presented the prospect of including building equity in her lease.

‚ÄúIt was one of those things where yes absolutely‚Äù Hunter said. ‚ÄúI would have put my coffee shop here either way. But absolutely I‚Äôd put my coffee shop here if I could be a part of this as more than just a business owner. As far as ownership goes that was just sugar on top. You can‚Äôt walk away from that. What other building would give me equity ownership with opening my business here?‚Äù

New builders and vanishing banks

Lavine and MacBride say they are hoping to amplify EastPoint and similar stories and get them heard in ‚Äúthe halls of power‚Äù to refocus on the new builders like Dodson and Sandino who are changing the odds for minority development and to also draw attention to the plight of small community banks like Castilla‚Äôs Citizens Bank of Edmond and Farmers Bank which financed the second phase of EastPoint.

‚ÄúOne of the most alarming trends is the massive consolidation of banks from 14000 just 20 years ago to 4800 now‚Äù Lavine said. ‚ÄúMany of those banks were community banks. We‚Äôve lost a lot of vibrancy in our banking system and that should alarm people. We can‚Äôt reverse that consolidation. But we can reverse some of the rules of the legislation that made this happen.‚Äù

Thompson who has traveled extensively said he has seen east side communities in middle market cities like Oklahoma City throughout the country.

‚ÄúBecause of this history of discrimination and systemic racism the history of overcoming these things is not unique to Oklahoma City‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to me that we did a development that has the potential to be a model elsewhere. I‚Äôve spent time in Tulsa on the Gulf Coast in Texas and Louisiana and there are communities that can benefit from the way we‚Äôre answering the challenges we‚Äôve run into.‚Äù

More:Buffalo Point Retreat & Event Center brings luxury lodging to small town Oklahoma

Staff writer Steve Lackmeyer is a 31-year reporter columnist and author who covers downtown Oklahoma City related urban development and economics for The Oklahoman. Contact him at slackmeyer@oklahoman.com. Please support his work and that of other Oklahoman journalists by purchasing a subscription today at subscribe.oklahoman.com.

Name: Clorox
Name_1: Rebranding to reflect our purpose
Text_1:
The Clorox Company has been making a positive difference in the world since 1913.

Through our namesake bleach we supported the war effort during World War II with a product that could disinfect wounds and neutralize enemy gases. And over the decades we‚Äôve helped communities recover from natural disasters by providing purified water when it‚Äôs contaminated and Glad¬Æ trash bags to help with clean-up.

Today in the midst of an ongoing global pandemic our company and brands have never been more relevant and our role in helping our communities never more important. The past year has crystallized our purpose to champion people to be well and thrive every single day.

With that purpose in mind we‚Äôve updated our corporate brand to better reflect the bigger role we play in society as we serve more people around the world.

First and foremost this rebrand reflects our people. Our shared values in how we work and treat one another. Our inclusive culture that puts people at the center of everything we do.

The modern and simple look of the rebrand depicts our forward-looking approach. The spectrum of colors is inspired by our house of brands and our diverse culture. The dynamic nature of the design embodies our innovative spirit and drive to grow our business the right way improving as we go and leaving the world better for the next generation.

While the familiar diamond is still at the core to honor our heritage the design scope has broadened to reflect the totality of what makes The Clorox Company what it is today. A company that‚Äôs built to continue to add value in a rapidly changing world. A company whose brands make a difference to people. And with a team committed to serving our consumers and communities.

Company
Name_2: Fabuloso: 5 Ways to Use This Virus-Vaporizing Cleaner in 2021
Text_2:
Editor's Note: Products featured on Wide Open Eats are independently selected by our editors. However when you buy something through our links we may earn a commission.

There are a lot of different household cleaners out there and it seems like each one is made for a different sort of tidying job. One brand is for your toilet bowl while another one specializes in cleaning your shower this one for your sink‚Äî and let's not mention how many different cleaning supplies there are just for your kitchen. That is... until we get to Fabuloso. One brand that can clean anything.

I love Clorox but Fabuloso brings all the different types of household cleaning products into one trusty brand (and without bleach). Although they have a different line of products for different purposes having them all under one roof means you know you're getting quality supplies no matter what you need to clean. Here are five different things you can clean with Fabuloso.

Best Fabuloso Cleaners

1. Wipe Down Glass:

Windex works well but I don't love having to buy a new spray bottle every time I run out. With Fabuloso All-Purpose I can get the streaks out of glass just as well and I don't have to go to the store every time I need a refill. Instead I can use Fabuloso concentrate to make a batch of cleaning supplies that will scrub streaks out of all my windows (and beyond).

The fresh scents of Fabuloso are tough to beat. There is Lemon Lavender and even a Passion Fruit scent. The mirrors in my bathroom are going to smell so good. Fortunately this large bottle of Fabuloso concentrate has a child safety cap on it that limits accessibility for youngins'. We don't want anyone mistaking the awesome smells as some tasty juice or anything.

2. Sealed Wood Surfaces:

I love Original Pine-Sol like a lot. However it's tough to find better pricing on a hardwood floor cleaner than what this 64-gallon bottle of Fabuloso brings to the table. With this concentrated formula you can have a hardwood cleaner that lasts for months.

Here's one disclaimer: make sure you're only using it on sealed hardwood. If your flooring is naturally finished Fabuloso could damage it. Otherwise enjoy the fresh lavender scent coming up from your floors!

3. Remove Grime From Your Grout or Countertops and Bathroom:

If you're having trouble deep cleaning your grout try spraying the lemon fresh scent of Fabuloso's multi-surface formula. Clean up is going to become so easy for you. Fabuloso's special formula (including lactic acid) will eat away grime wherever it hides and leave your bathroom sparkling clean.

In addition to cleaning out mildew and grime you can also use Fabuloso Complete to remove limescale and as a disinfectant spray. And it kills 99% of germs. Your move Lysol.

4. Easy Disinfectant Cleaner:

Fabuloso's Disinfecting Wipes make fighting viruses (including our least favorite one) a breeze. Fabuloso states their disinfecting wipes have been proven to kill the COVID-19 virus on non-porous surfaces. Keep a pack of these wipes in your purse backpack car or office. You'll breathe a sigh of relief knowing your space is protected from any bad germs.

5. Kitchen Degreaser:

The fresh scent of lavender makes an awesome kitchen degreaser too. The Professional formula cuts through stovetop grease without any rinsing necessary. All you have to do is spray and wipe away your kitchen messes. The formula has a neutral pH so that you can use it on other supplies too but it's good to know your stovetop will be cleaner than ever.

Prime two-day delivery is easier than sitting in line for an in-store pickup of your favorite cleaning supplies. Take my credit card already Fabuloso!
Name_3: Massimo introduces first artisanal sandwich loaf for lockdown
Text_3:
The Massimo Seeded Multigrain with Barley loaf uses premium Canadian barley for a rich nutty taste.

The Italian Baker Sdn Bhd maker of Massimo breads and baked goods has announced a new bread named Massimo Seeded Multigrain with Barley for healthy eating at home during lockdown.

Jeremy Goon chairman of The Italian Baker said bread consumption has increased among Malaysians who are mostly staying home to protect themselves and their loved ones during the Covid-19 pandemic.

‚ÄúEmbracing a nutritious diet is essential for us to continue staying healthy especially given our current circumstances where we are eating at home more often.

‚ÄúHence our bakers food scientists nutritionists and research and development team worked closely together to develop our first-ever artisanal multigrain loaf by carefully balancing between nutrition and taste.‚Äù

The Italian Baker Sdn Bhd chairman Jeremy Goon.

Goon said the Massimo team collected and analyzed relevant consumer data and key learnings from the first Movement Control Order (MCO 1.0) as well as from various Malaysian health statistics including the National Health and Morbidity (NHMS) Survey 2019.

‚ÄúThe Massimo Seeded Multigrain with Barley loaf was then developed to cultivate healthier eating habits while continuing to satiate the cravings and palate of Malaysians‚Äù he added.

The artisanal Massimo Seeded Multigrain with Barley loaf 360g.



The Massimo Seeded Multigrain with Barley loaf features an artisanal multigrain loaf enriched with premium Canadian barley flaxseed chia seed sunflower seed and black sesame which are packed with vitamins and minerals.

The first artisanal sandwich loaf serves up a winning combination of the bread maker‚Äôs fine bread-making tradition and the unique taste and well-researched functional food benefits of barley.

The Massimo Seeded Multigrain with Barley loaf (360g) which is an ideal choice for sandwiches toast or simply on its own is available for a limited time only at most retailers at RM4.90.

Name: CME Group
Name_1: Gold price charts: Frank Holmes on metal's golden cross - MINING.COM
Text_1:
Credit: US Global Investors

In the past this has been a bullish indicator of gold prices. According to Holmes gold was still trading about 12% lower from its all-time high set last summer.

In the short to medium term it appears as if gold demand will continue to be driven by central bank policy which should remain accommodative even as inflation fears increase.

According to the CME Group‚Äôs FedWatch Tool there‚Äôs a 75% probability that interest rates will stay in the 0.00% to 0.25% range a year from now leaving plenty of time for gold to test $2000 per oz. or more.

‚ÄúI favour gold as a portfolio diversifier. Low bond yields have pushed investors into riskier assets including stocks. ‚ÄúThis has been a winning strategy as major indices have been hitting all-time highs but it‚Äôs important to maintain a position in gold to help manage risk. I recommend a 10% weighting with 5% in physical gold and 5% in gold stocks.‚Äù

This week spot gold closed at $1808.32 up $21.02 per oz or 1.18%. As measured by the NYSE Arca Gold Miners Index gold stocks ended the week lower by 0.12%.

CLICK HERE for an interactive gold price chart

MINING.COM

Central banks from Serbia to Thailand have been adding to their gold holdings writes Bloomberg this week and Ghana recently announced plans for purchases as the spectre of accelerating inflation looms. A recovery in global trade provides the firepower to make purchases.

A rebound in buying which had dropped to the lowest in a decade would bolster the prospects for gold prices as some other sources of demand falter reports Bloomberg.

The worst performing precious metal for the week was silver down 1.39% after two consecutive weekly gains.

The worst performing precious metal for the week was silver down 1.39% after two consecutive weekly gains. Bank of America lowered its 2021 silver price forecast 3.9% to $27.71 per oz. Despite this they prefer silver due to the rising demand for solar panels and electrical applications.

The major market indices finished mixed this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.24% and the S&P 500 Stock Index rose 0.43%. Meanwhile the Nasdaq Composite climbed 0.43% while the Russell 2000 small capitalization index lost 1.13% this week.

The S&P/TSX Venture Index came in off 3.09%. The 10-year Treasury bond yield fell six basis points to 1.36%.

Name: CMS Energy
Name_1: Why consumers have to pay high rates for power in Rajasthan
Text_1:
High power purchase cost:

Bulging interest cost on discoms‚Äô loans:

High depreciation cost more low paying users:

Other reasons:

Timely tariff hikes could have avoided more hikes:

JAIPUR: In Rajasthan  people pay one of the highest rates for power. The natural disadvantage of being located far away from coal resources resulting in power purchasing cost of Rs 4.81 per unit highest in the country along with UP is not the only reason. The interest burden of discoms‚Äô loans is another major reason. In fact at Rs 1.40 per unit of power the interest paid by discoms for its loans is the highest in the country.Recently the board of state energy department decided to exit from high power purchase agreements to bring down the cost of power.Also a proposal from the Rajasthan Vidyut Utpadan Nigam Ltd for retiring two units of Kota Super Thermal Power Station having 220 megawatt pending with the government.In the past financial year discoms used cheaper electricity from power exchanges and brought down the purchasing costs by Rs 20 paisa per unit but the impact of legacy burden and natural disadvantages is too large to pass on the benefits to the consumers. But more such strategies are being discussed to reduce the power tariffs in state which are one of the highest in the country.TOI analyses the causes as to what led to the spike in power rates in the state and why it is proving difficult for the government to provide relief.This contributes nearly 80% to the total cost of supply of the discoms. The conventional thermal power plants have been using coal transported from outside the state and the high logistics cost is making power generation expensive. Power purchase cost of Rajasthan at Rs 4.81 kWh which is about Rs 0.08 kWh higher than national average of Rs 4.73 kWh. For other states‚Äô (excluding UP) power purchase costs are below all India average. In some states it is half in comparison to Rajasthan.From unbundling of discoms in 2000 till 2011 there were only two tariff revisions. While costs increased by 71% during this period revenue increased by 2% only. Discoms had to take short term loans to fund these increase in costs. After 2011 there have been some tariff revisions but by then the interest costs had gone up. Non-timely tariff revisions and no tariff hikes in 2016-17 2017-18 and 2018-19 forced discoms to fund losses through loans. As a result the interest cost has gone up and it is highest in the country.Rajasthan is the largest state in the country with very low population density. So the cost of infrastructure per consumer is the highest in the country. Infrastructure requires both higher capital expenditure and depreciation cost. Also Rajasthan has amongst the highest share of consumers in the country at low tension level (domestic and agriculture). This results in higher technical and transformer losses.Cheap hydro sources constitute less than 10% of the power portfolio in Rajasthan whereas other neighboring states have much higher cheap hydro power share. The state also faces huge variation between peak demand (14000mw) and average demand (9500mw) due to which discoms are liable to pay fixed charges even if no power is procured from generation companies. Thirdly even with availability of low cost renewable energy discoms will continue to pay fixed charges of long term agreements with conventional generators.From 2007-08 to 2013-14 the cost of supply had nearly doubled but the rates were nearly half of the cost which resulted in heavy losses to the discoms and loan liabilities. If the discoms were able to revise their tariffs regularly by 3-4% annually in line with inflation it would have avoided the need for large and sudden tariff hikes and the impact on consumers would have been minimized.

Name: Coca-Cola Company
Name_1: Ministry of Foreign Affairs Acknowledges Coke Studio's Role in Promoting Pakistani Culture
Text_1:
The Honourable Foreign Minister of Pakistan Makhdoom Shah Mahmood Qureshi said ‚ÄúHistory tells us that the subtle forces of cultural diplomacy have impact and can create understanding among peoples from different backgrounds. I am therefore delighted to collaborate with Coke Studio to bring Pakistan‚Äôs true image to the world: one of optimism youth unity and peace.‚Äù He also added that the book will be sent to each of the Pakistani embassies across the globe.



Fahad Ashraf VP and General Manager at The Coca‚ÄëCola Export Corporation for Pakistan & Afghanistan region said ‚ÄúWe are honoured to receive this recognition from The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and be able to collaborate on Coke Studio‚Äôs musical journey. I want to thank everyone who has contributed to the arts and culture of our nation and to Coke Studio‚Äôs bridge-building legacy in the past 14 years.‚Äù

Name_3: Meet Pamela Cook of Coca-Cola UNITED
Text_3:
Share with your friends! 151 SHARES 1 Pinterest LinkedIn Email

Many companies and corporations across the country are abuzz about diversity and inclusion. Pamela Cook helps to make sure that Birmingham-based Coca-Cola UNITED ‚Äî the second-largest privately held Coca-Cola bottler in North America and the third-largest bottler of Coke products in the United States ‚Äî walks the walk. She serves as Director of Multicultural Marketing & Community Affairs for the company‚Äôs Central Region which includes Alabama the Panhandle of Florida the Tennessee Valley area and parts of southwest Georgia. As part of her job Pamela also cultivates Coca-Cola UNITED‚Äôs partnerships with Historically Black Colleges and Universities or HBCUs. Even when she‚Äôs not at work Pamela keeps busy serving the Birmingham community by volunteering with several organizations. We‚Äôre honored to introduce our latest FACE of Birmingham Pamela Cook.

You‚Äôve served in your current role at Coca-Cola UNITED since 2018 and have been with the company since 2014. What do you enjoy most about your job?

I love that no two days are the same. Every day is its own adventure. I love how marketing continues to evolve. And I enjoy the people ‚Äî I like what the company stands for.

Is there anything you‚Äôve seen companies get wrong when it comes to diversity and inclusion or multi-cultural marketing? What are you doing to make sure Coca-Cola UNITED doesn‚Äôt make these mistakes?

Each company has to take that journey for themselves so I can‚Äôt speak to what they‚Äôre doing wrong. But inside our organization we took a very proactive approach and we started a diversity and inclusion council. In June during our Diversity & Inclusion Week we held a number of events across our company including ‚ÄúJoin the Conversation‚Äù where our CEO and vice presidents were having difficult talks about race and gender equality. We traveled with a film crew to capture stories from our associates about diversity and asked them to tell us about their families and how they grew up. We hosted Friendship Day and had cookouts at all of our locations. It was all about learning more about the people you go to work with every day.

RELATED: Meet This Birmingham Social Media Sensation

Part of your job focuses on nurturing partnerships between Coca-Cola UNITED and HBCUs. What are some of the things your company does to serves these schools?

One of the partnerships is our Pay It Forward program. It‚Äôs an internship for students. They learn how the Coke gets from the warehouse to the stores and the marketing that goes into it. We line them up with professionals inside our organization whose jobs match their majors or their areas of interest or we introduce them to a new opportunity they hadn‚Äôt even thought about. They spend time with our executive leadership. How many college students get to sit down and have lunch with a CEO of a company and then take selfies for the rest of the day with them? We give them $1000 for their time with us because what student doesn‚Äôt need a little bit of money in their pocket when they go back to school?

Why do you feel these partnerships are important?

It‚Äôs just the right thing to do. We want to give back to the communities ‚Äî to the consumers ‚Äî who buy our products. We make a point to reinvest in the communities that we live work and serve in and HBCU communities are a part of that. Our schools are so much more than half-time homecoming and classics. HBCUs birth game changers thought leaders CEOs scientists doctors ‚Äì there‚Äôs so much talent inside of an HBCU. It‚Äôs my privilege to be their champion inside of our organization and to work with amazing students educators and presidents.

You‚Äôre a native of Huntsville Alabama but you‚Äôve been in Birmingham for more than 20 years. What do you love most about the Magic City?

I‚Äôve met some really amazing people on my journey here. I like that it‚Äôs a city that‚Äôs big enough to be active but small enough to still have a great sense of community. There‚Äôs so much potential here. I‚Äôve seen a lot of change in the city and I want to see it continue to grow and expand.

Tell us more about some of the community service that you do.

I participated for years with Project Homeless Connect. It‚Äôs such a great way to give back to the community. In just a few hours you can help somebody on their journey. I‚Äôm serving now on the board for Red Mountain Theatre Company. I love theater and I always want other people to experience theater. The arts mean so much to our daily lives. We don‚Äôt realize how much of a role it plays in our living thinking being and our sense of community. I also have the great pleasure of working on the upcoming World Games. I‚Äôm really excited about that and what it will mean for our city. It‚Äôs that once-in-a-lifetime activity. Our city is going to be spotlighted in ways that it never has been.

RELATED: Pamela Reed Phipps: Birmingham‚Äôs Champion for Girls in Foster Care

What do you like to do when you‚Äôre not working?

Amazon Prime and I have been in a toxic relationship. I‚Äôve been shopping a lot. During the pandemic I started getting more into self-care. So I‚Äôm making time to go get a facial or a massage. Or I will go for a walk and leave the technology at home and listen to nature. I also fell in love with exercise. I started working with a trainer at Train & Burn.

What was your last best meal at a BHM restaurant?

The chicken and waffles at Yo‚Äô Mama‚Äôs.

What is your favorite hidden gem in BHM?

Cayo Coco. It‚Äôs a rum bar and it‚Äôs like stepping into Cuba. They have fabulous food and marvelous drinks and they‚Äôre environmentally friendly.

Where did you go on your last vacation?

I went to Sandestin for a few days earlier this year. That‚Äôs one of my favorite places to drive away to. My last international trip before the shutdown was to Barbados. That‚Äôs a great country to go visit.

What‚Äôs on your bedside table?

The Alchemist ‚Äì I like to reread that from time to time.

What is your go-to birthday present to give?

I like to give something meaningful. I want to give them something they wouldn‚Äôt buy themselves. It‚Äôs never a gift card.

What‚Äôs the best advice you can give?

Surround yourself with people who are where you want to be and they will absolutely pull you up.

Name three things you can‚Äôt live without.

Peanut M&Ms my big comfy chair at home and people.

Thank you Pamela! All photography by J&M Photography and Design.

**********

To meet more inspiring Birmingham women visit our FACES archives.
